indicators.justification:
Emissions information is not available as open data, some datasets can be found in international websites such as: World Bank Data platform (2), and others. Unfortunately there is no publication by government.

There is a National Climate Change Policy(1), the policy scopes include reducing vulnerability to extreme weather events, strengthening adaptive capacity and taking advantage of opportunities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

(1) https://www.marn.gob.gt/Multimedios/18647.pdf

(2) World Bank Data https://datos.bancomundial.org/indicator/EN.ATM.GHGT.ZG?locations=GT

indicators.justification:
The vital statistics that the INE generates cover vital events that occurred during the reference year, based on the event's date of occurrence. The INE generates statistics six months after the end of the year to take into account registrations made up to six months after the year's end for the previous year. The main source of vital statistics for the INE is RENAP. RENAP registers events through its decentralized network of registry offices and submits consolidated databases to the INE (in a flat file format) during the first eight days of each month: it provides information about births, marriages, and deaths that occurred in the preceding month. The INE receives and reviews the data to validate its consistency. If the data meets its standards, INE prepares the vital statistics database and codifies the data (especially cause of death). The data is then analyzed and published on its portal, where it is available for national and international users to consult.

Sources:
(1) ESTADÍSTICAS DE VITALES - INE
https://www.ine.gob.gt/estadisticasine/index.php/usuario/vitales_menu

(2) CRVS Guatemala
https://crvssystems.ca/sites/default/files/assets/files/CRVS_GuatemalaSnapshot_e_Web.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Guatemalan Ministry of Health implemented a dashboard in which relevant data on the COVID-19 pandemic are presented. The dashboard presents data at the municipal level of positive cases, deaths, vaccination and databases. It is important to note that cases are usually reported days after death due to the individualized investigation time and the notification process. Each day, deceased cases reported the day before will be added by dates of death.

Sources
(1) MSPAS COVID 19 Dashboard
https://tablerocovid.mspas.gob.gt/

Guatemala data of Government budget and spending information (budget execution)is available from the Ministry of Public Finance of Guatemala (MINFIN).
Data of Government budget and spending information (budget execution)is available from the Ministry of Public Finance of Guatemala (MINFIN) portals. indicators.justification:
The political finance information of Guatemala is not available in Open Data format or online. The information can only be accessed by attending an office to inspect it or by a solicitation using the Freedom of Information Act.

The Supreme Electoral Tribunal (TSE) of Guatemala is the governing body of the information, but there is no evidence of open data of the information on its web portal.

Sources: 

(1) Supreme Electoral Tribunal (TSE) -https://www.tse.org.gt/

indicators.justification:
The Minister of Public Finances of Guatemala has two main data portals of the public procurement. The national procurement portal, Guatecompras(1), has all the information of the procurement data. The Open data portal(2) has the procurement data in the open data formats like XLS, CSV and JSON.

(1): Guatecompras. Minister of Public Finances of Guatemala (MINFIN). In Spanish only: https://www.guatecompras.gt/
(2): Fiscal Open Data Portal. Minister of Public Finances of Guatemala (MINFIN). In Spanish only: https://datos.minfin.gob.gt/

indicators.justification:
In Guatemala there are efforts and commitments (1) on the part of the Government of Guatemala for the implementation of the open data initiative. In 2018, the National Open Data Policy of Guatemala (2) was formulated and approved through Government Agreement 199-2018 (3), in which it was established that the governing body of said policy would be the Ministry of the Interior with the support of the Presidential Commission for Open Public Management and Transparency. The Policy has a temporality of 2018 to 2022 and is based on the principles of the International Open Data Charter. The National Institute of Public Administration (INAP) committed itself to the 3rd National Open Government Plan and the National Open Data Policy to design, schedule and periodically execute training on the subject of open data (4).
 
General open data awareness and training programs for public officials are in place to ensure that they are able to use open data effectively. The publication of data is considered part of the government's regular performance indicators and progress reports are available.
 
## Sources
(1): Commitment 5. 3rd National Open Government Plan. Alliance for an Open Government. https://www.opengovpartnership.org/es/members/guatemala/commitments/GT0067/ (2): National Open Data Policy. http://mingob.gob.gt/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Politica-Nacional-de-Datos-Abificios-2018-2022.pdf
(3): Governmental Agreement 199-2018. Approval of the National Open Data Policy. https://www.minfin.gob.gt/index.php/legislacion/acuerdos-gubernativos/acuerdos-gubernativos-2018/5043-no-199-2018-acuerdo-gubernativo-mingob-acuerdese-aprobar-la-politica- national-open-data-2018-2022-formulated-by-the-ministry-of-government-jointly-with-the-national-secretariat-of-science-and-technology
(4): National Open Data Policy. F. TRAINING ON OPEN DATA http://mingob.gob.gt/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Politica-Nacional-de-Datos-Abificios-2018-2022.pdf

indicators.justification:
Guatemala has no specific legal framework for protection of personal data. Guatemala also does not have a regulatory authority that is responsible for controlling the use of personal data, its transfer, processing, commercialisation, and in general terms, its protection. In addition, attempts to issue specific regulation have failed. But there are alternative norms or laws that play a partial role in protection of personal data.

The Political Constitution of the Republic of Guatemala ('the Constitution') recognises privacy and data privacy rights as a constitutional right. (1) Articles one to five of the Political Constitution of the Republic of Guatemala implicitly recognises the right to human dignity and human rights that encompass a right to privacy. Article 23 of the Constitution also recognises dignity and the right to privacy in establishing the inviolability of housing, and Article 24 of the Constitution recognises the inviolability of every individual's correspondence, documents, and book-keeping, and provides that the privacy of correspondence by telephone, radio, cable, and other modes of modern digital technology is guaranteed. Furthermore, Article 30 of the Constitution establishes the public nature of administrative acts and recognises that individuals have the right to obtain public information from the administration. Article 31 of the Constitution determines that any individual has the right to know about all private and personal information recorded in public registries, and has the right to know about the purpose for which such information is recorded, as well as having the right to correct, rectify, and update such information. 

Decree No. 57-2008 on the Law on Access to Public Information ('the Law on Access to Public Information'), introduces key data protection concepts such as personal data and sensitive personal data (2). Nevertheless, the subject matter of this law is to secure the access to public information that is in possession of public authorities and obligated entities under the Law on Access to Public Information. The article 64 of the Law on Access to Public Information regulates the commercialisation of personal data and imposes sanctions (fines and imprisonment) to those that distribute, by any means, files containing personal data or sensitive personal data, which do not come from public registries, without the written consent of the data subject. 

In a decision issued by the Constitutional Court, Case No. 3552-2014 of 10 February 2015 ('Case 3552-2014'), where the Ombudsman of Human Rights ('the Ombudsman') had filed a case against various private entities accused of gathering and commercialising private information from individuals without their consent. (3) Case 1356-2006 was emblematic in the sense that it was the first case in which the Constitutional Court decided to afford data privacy protection despite the absence of a law regulating this matter in detail. In particular, the Constitutional Court outlined, 'Once a person's right to determine the existence or nonexistence of registries or databases containing his/her personal data is recognised, as well as their right to obtain the rectification, deletion or blocking thereto if the incorrect use of the data may affect his/her intimacy and honour, the manner in which the judicial protection of such rights can be requested must be determined. It is known that in comparative law and in accordance with procedural constitutional modern doctrine, the protection of such rights is done through the action of 'habeas data', which has not been regulated in Guatemala. This case is important and of great relevance because it introduced the right to privacy in Guatemala in the absence of specific data protection legislation.

In the absence of such a law, and while such a situation prevails in the country, this court holds that given the nature and ample scope of the constitutional remedy of legal actions such as 'amparo', amparo is the appropriate constitutional action destined to guarantee the right of every person to access their personal data kept in private or official databases or registries.'



## Sources
(1):  Political Constitution Of The Republic Of Guatemala. Congress of the Republic of Guatemala. https://www.congreso.gob.gt/assets/uploads/secciones/pdf/16e67-constitucion-politica-de-la-republica-de-guatemala.pdf
(2): The Law on Access to Public Information. Congress of the Republic of Guatemala. https://www.congreso.gob.gt/assets/uploads/transparencia/idiomas_pdf/LEY_DE_ACCESO_A_LA_INFORMACION_PUBLICA.pdf 
(3): Constitutional Court of Guatemala, decision issued on file 3552-2014 on February 10, 2015. Only available in Spanish at: https://jurisprudencia.cc.gob.gt/portal/Expediente.aspx

evidence.title: Political Constitution Of The Republic Of Guatemala
The Law on Access to Public Information
Constitutional Court of Guatemala, decision issued on file 3552-2014 on February 10, 2015.

There are digital services that are carrying out checks before entering into a financial relationship with a company, such as signing a contract with a supplier or opening a bank account for a company.

One or more products/services exist, but they do not appear to make use of open datasets. They get the information by access of information requests or private access information.

It was very hard to find information regarding the section, mainly the due diligence information is from private sector. There are some products or services used by private sectors, banks and others to review the hiring of personal.
As well, for financial improvements and loans.

Sources: 
https://infor.net/portal/
https://www.grantthornton.gt/Servicios/Consultoria/

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist, but they do not appear to make use of open datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of actors using land data to influence land policies, through a variety of means in Guatemala. Actions go from papers, reports, events, tools, and forums—and be produced by a range of stakeholders, including journalists, lobbyists, NGOs, grassroot organizations, academics, and others. 
Promoting awareness of the challenges for excluded communities in Guatemala.

Land tenure information in not available as open data, can only be accessed in the General Property Registration by the use of Public Information Access Law and legal actions through lawyer and notary.

It was hard to obtain information of land use in Guatemala.  The website for the General Property Registration only contains data about the registration procedures and information, can only be accessed by the Public Information Access Law and legal actions through lawyer and notary.

SOURCES:
(1) http://www.fao.org/tenure/activities/policies-laws/policyreformsinguatemala/en/
(2) https://www.pnas.org/content/109/31/12408.short
(3) https://www.rgp.org.gt/index.php/informatcion-publica
indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion

indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of civil society actors or entities using this data for accountability purposes. Civil Society organizations use data to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government, examples like: Accion Ciudadana (TI chapter), Icefi, Dialogos, Red Ciudadana, Ojo con mi Pisto, and others
Some of the projects have impacted the selection of public officers, some legal actions against public officers, and initiated the investigation for CICIG actions in our country.

(1) Plaza Publica - https://www.plazapublica.com.gt/
(2) Red Ciudadana - https://redciudadana.org/
(3) Accion Ciudadana - https://accionciudadanagt.org/
(4) ICEFI - https://www.icefi.org/

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification: There is some evidence of procurement data being used to produce insights and knowledge, and to support decision-making: https://ojo-publico.com/1928/coronacompras-mascarillas-con-sobreprecio-en-america-latina

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
